Award.AwardTitle: Building an Ecology of Online Laboratories
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this catalytic project, the Center for Educational Computing Initiatives at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is partnering with the Spanish University of Distance Education (UNED) and the University of Deusto, Spain. The first goal is the expansion and integration of MIT?s iLabs Shared Architecture (ISA) with an open source learning management system (LMS) using SCORM standards. The coupling of online labs with LMSs will allow a particular experiment to be customized for multiple educational environments and for the learning objectives of the lab experience to be carefully tracked and evaluated. The second goal is to develop a specification for interoperability between two remote lab architectures (ISA & WebLab-Deusto) and create a plan for infrastructure changes to both architectures to enable interoperability and develop a proof of concept implementation. The increased interoperability between different online lab architectures and learning management systems will both lead to an increasing scalable ecology of online labs.

Online laboratories in general have the potential to transform STEM education by enabling students to actively participate in global collaborations through access to unique and exciting laboratories. They enable new communities of researchers and students to explore phenomena, and jointly engage in scientific inquiry with world-wide partners. This project contributes by: 1) creating an interoperability specification that details the requirements to enable the sharing of online laboratory across architectures and will drastically increase the number of labs available; 2) creation of a shared global resource of online labs and sharable curricular materials that students have access to in the course of their academic careers; and 3) engaging students in unique and exciting scientific experiments that will hopefully capture their interest in science and engineering fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Remote Laboratories are software and hardware solutions that enable students to conduct experiments on real equipment over the Internet. Remote Labs have the potential to address the disappearing laboratory experiences in STEM education today and engage student interest through experimentation and exploration.  Unlike conventional laboratories, remote labs have the ability of being shared between universities and around the world.

There are several different remote lab architectures around the world, each built on different platforms with different services and infrastructure. MIT and the University of Deusto each have an online laboratory architecture that is currently used by students on their own campus and at other institutions. There are similarities between the architectures, but the interfaces and implementations are different. What is needed is a way for different architecture to communicate and share laboratory resources through interoperability. Interoperability is the ability of resources developed under one remote lab architecture to be used by other architectures; it is not the re-engineering of both systems into a common implementation.
Developing a system to manage the interoperability between existing architectures (iLab and WebLab-Deusto) and an existing opensource Learning Management Systems (dotLRN and Moodle) is a key step forward. By understanding the process for establishing interoperability and developing an interoperability standard other universities can use this work as a guide to enable the sharing of their labs.

A key interoperability objective is to expand the availability of educational resources and the variety of devices available to all types of learners around the world and to sustain this growth over time.This project is the first step in creating a shared global resource for students. It is about access to exceptional and unique laboratory experiences that will not only excite students but encourage them to explore and hopefully hook them on science and engineering.

In collaboration with UNED and the University of Deusto, this project has expanded the iLab architecture to support automatic logins from Learning Management Systems and designed a prototype module that can launch an iLab experiment through a Sharable Content Object (SCO).   To achieve interoperability between different remote lab architectures, we developed the idea of a federated system of remote laboratories and specified the requirements for a multi-architecture laboratory manager (LabManager).  The LabManager is a software module that provides an set of interfaces between different remote laboratories architectures enabling the sharing of laboratories between universities. By necessity, the LabManager needs to impact the local university architecture as little as possible, be seamless for the students and faculty, and pass information in both directions.

This project involved three groups, each with extensive and complementary experience with online laboratories and programs.
